phrase: The engine cranks but will not start. There is no spark coming from the ignition coil, which has failed internally.
Coolant is found leaking from the side of the engine block. A steel freeze plug has rusted through and is weeping fluid.
Coolant is mixing with the engine oil causing emulsion. The intake manifold gasket is deteriorated and allowing coolant to seep into the cylinders.
Fuel leaks from the bottom of the carburetor and creates a fire hazard. The float bowl gasket is hardened and cracked from age and heat cycling.
The application of the brakes produces a grinding noise and sensitivity to the pedal. The brake pads are worn out, and the caliper piston is broken.
The battery won't hold charge for more than a few days. Even when the vehicle is not in use, the system experiences constant wear and tear, and the alternator belt becomes loose.
When the engine is not running, the carburetor drips fuel. The float needle valve is damaged and does not sit properly to prevent fuel from discharging.
There is a visible puddle of fuel under the engine bay. A rubber fuel line has become brittle and cracked, causing a dangerous leak.
The car's left-hand braking action is abrupt, and it pulls away from the right front brake caliper slide pins. This prevents it from applying pressure while pulling backward.
The engine turns off while driving over bumps. A main ground wire from the engine to the chassis is loose.
Delay, loud clunk, low transmission fluid, burn smell as I try to shift from Park to Drive.

There are white, crusty deposits around the thermostat housing. The gasket has failed and is causing a slow coolant leak.
The fuel gauge remains at full capacity, regardless of the actual fuel level. The sending unit float arm is damaged within the fuel tank.
When shifting into third gear, the manual transmission will grind. The synchronizer rings are worn out and the shift fork is bent due to previous hard shifting.

The engine experiences a sudden power reduction and backfires while accelerating. The ignition timing is severely delayed, according to the findings.
The car's horn and radio activate automatically. Water damage has affected the BCM, which is not functioning properly.
The vehicle loses power when the air conditioning is turned on. The fuel pump cycles on and off audibly and the engine hesitates when under load.
The engine's performance is poor and the check engine light indicates a problem with the camshaft position sensor, leading to incorrect ignition and fuel timing.
The power windows will go down but not up. The master window switch on the driver's door has failed.
